primary_legislative_goal.policy_objective: Establish federal standards for data breach notification and consumer data protection
primary_legislative_goal.preferred_vehicle: H.R. 8888 - Comprehensive Data Privacy Act (standalone bill)
primary_legislative_goal.committee: House Energy and Commerce - Consumer Protection Subcommittee
primary_legislative_goal.status: MARKUP_BLOCKED - Opposition from tech industry and some committee members

option_1.name: Narrowed Scope Bill
option_1.description: Reduce scope to data breach notification only, remove broader privacy provisions
pros: Lower opposition - data breach notification has broader support
Fits Energy and Commerce jurisdiction cleanly
Can build on existing state law precedents
cons: May reduce momentum for comprehensive privacy legislation

option_2.name: Rider on Must-Pass Vehicle
option_2.description: Attach data breach notification provisions to must-pass appropriations or authorization bill
option_2.vehicle: FY2027 Commerce, Justice, Science Appropriations or NDAA
pros: Can bypass Energy and Commerce if included in appropriations
cons: Appropriations riders face points of order
Limited scope due to vehicle constraints

option_3.name: State Law Preemption Approach
option_3.description: Federal standard that preempts state laws but sets minimum floor (not ceiling)
pros: Addresses industry concern about patchwork of state laws
Can attract industry support by providing uniformity
Maintains stronger state protections where they exist
cons: Preemption language controversial with states' rights advocates
May lose consumer advocacy support if seen as weakening protections
option_3.timeline: 3-4 months for revision and coalition rebuilding

option_4.name: Sector-Specific Approach
option_4.description: Start with healthcare or financial services data (already have sectoral privacy laws)
option_4.vehicle: Amendment to existing sectoral privacy laws or new sectoral bill
pros: Can expand to other sectors over time
cons: Incremental approach, may take years to achieve comprehensive coverage
Each sector requires separate legislative effort

option_5.name: Executive Action + Report Language
option_5.description: Support Administration rulemaking or executive order, plus appropriations report language
option_5.vehicle: Executive order + CJS Appropriations report language
pros: Can achieve some policy goals without congressional action
cons: Executive actions can be reversed by future administrations
Limited authority for comprehensive privacy regulation

recommended_strategy.primary_path: Option 1 - Narrowed scope bill focusing on data breach notification
recommended_strategy.rationale: Highest viability, achieves meaningful progress, can build momentum for broader legislation later
parallel_paths: Continue advocating for comprehensive bill for future Congress
Support Option 4 for high-priority sectors (healthcare data breaches are urgent)
recommended_strategy.abandon_if: None - all options advance policy goals to some degree

when_to_activate_fallback: Primary vehicle fails committee vote or is indefinitely delayed
Opposition is intractable and compromise unlikely
Legislative calendar constraints require faster action
Administration signals support for alternative approach
option_selection_factors: Policy impact (how much of goal is achieved)
Coalition maintenance (does option maintain key supporter relationships)

coalition_management.maintain_supporters: Communicate that fallback options are strategic, not abandonment of comprehensive goals
coalition_management.address_concerns: Some advocates may see fallbacks as 'selling out' - need clear communication about long-term strategy
coalition_management.opposition_response: Fallback options may actually reduce opposition by addressing their concerns (narrower scope, preemption)

disclaimer: Fallback options represent strategic flexibility when primary legislative path is blocked. Selection should balance policy goals, political reality, and long-term strategy.
